content.description: Start in a shallow corner with a bolt just off the deck. Climb to a large ledge and scramble up onto a detached boulder/flake to clip the second bolt. A few slabby moves get you into a right-facing corner. Clip a high bolt where the corner feature peters out. Step left across a blunt arete (crux). Positive holds in a large crack deliver you to the anchors.
content.location:
It is the first bolted line right of

Annie's Arete

.

content.description: This climb is a little wander-y around trees and blocks and goes into a neat, right-facing crack/corner. There are some iffy gear placements, but this has fun crack rasslin'.
content.location:
From where the trail meets the ledge, head left past one belay bolt and

Slab Happy

. This is the obvious crack/corner up high with a few bolts down low and one up high.

content.description:
This is easily one of the best routes in the 12- range at The Pool Wall. It has sustained climbing with distinctive cruxes.

Start on a moderate face with one belay bolt and two protection bolts which leads to a large ledge. From the ledge, a sequency section of crimpy and powerful climbing leads up just left of the bolt line to a roof. Surmount the roof via slopers and crimps, try to shake out at the sloping ledge, then embark up the finishing face of sidepulls and fingerlocks. This is a great route on superb rock. The original grade in the guidebook was 11d/12a. 12- feels about right for the onsight grade.
content.location: Start directly above where the approach trail meets the ledge.

content.description: This is yet another tricky Pool Wall 5.10. This route starts at a belay bolt just left of where the approach trail meets the wall. Follow a couple bolts up a face, through a shallow roof, up moderate terrain, to a crux slab section which ends with another small roof. The moves seem improbable at first, but it's all there. A broken hold at the end of the crux has made the sequence a little more reachy and a bit more dynamic to the last roof. This is a good route that will test your slabbing skills.

Guillotine is mostly hands with a short off-widthy section. Crack climb just left of

Annie's Arete

. This climb has been recently excavated with many loose blocks trundled.
content.protection: Bring extra hand-sized pieces. You should not need anything bigger than a #3 Camalot. There are rap rings at the top.
content.location:
This is the obvious corner crack in the dihedral just left of

Annie's Arete

.

content.description:
This is a hard route that climbs through a series of roofs just right of

Talent Pool

. The crux is above the biggest roof.
content.location:
It is just right of

Talent Pool

, where the approach trail meets the ledge.

content.description:
This is one of the only real crack climbs at the Pool Wall. And, it's pretty darn good. Climbs up the great wide crack just right of the Ginsu Arete (

Look Sharp

&

Be Sharp

). When you get to the wide bit there is actually a nice finger crack right next to it, so no wide gear is necessary. It ends at chains on the left wall.
content.protection: An assortment of finger- and hands-sized gear.
content.location:
This is just right of

Look Sharp

&

Be Sharp

, at the right side of the

Bay of Pigs

.

content.description: Start in a crack shattered corner, and climb to a ledge. Climb a short section of bolt-protected corner crack. Traverse out to the arete.
content.protection: There are approximately 8 bolts to chains.
content.location: It is located on the rightmost arete feature at the Wading Pool Area. The approach trail comes in from the right.
